coverage_summary: This policy provides legal expenses insurance for landlords with let properties (excluding their primary residence). It covers legal costs arising from contract disputes, property protection issues, legal defence for prosecutions related to letting, and identity theft. The policy includes a 24/7 free legal advice service and covers professional fees up to £50,000 per policy period.
key_inclusions: Contract disputes for buying/hiring goods or services
Contract disputes for selling goods you own
Property protection claims for physical damage to property at let property
Nuisance or trespass claims relating to let property
Legal defence against prosecutions arising from letting your let property
Identity theft costs reimbursement up to £5,000
Lost wages/salary when attending court or police (up to £200 per day)
Professional fees up to £50,000 per policy period
Defendant's costs if ordered to pay
key_exclusions: Where let property is HMO, B&B or hotel
Any claims related to letting activity or against a tenant
Claims where you don't own the property without written authority to sub-let
Disputes between insured persons or family members
Small claims (limited to legal advice only)
Claims without reasonable prospects of success
Items sold at auction or through auction websites
Boundary disputes (except at let property after 180 days)
Prosecutions where advised to plead guilty
Claims where Legal Aid not applied for
Identity theft caused by failure to safeguard personal information

coverage_limits.maximum_amount_per_policy_period: £50,000 total including professional fees and defendants costs for one or more claims
coverage_limits.property_protection_excess: £250 excess for nuisance or trespass claims
coverage_limits.property_protection_minimum: No cover for matters where value of loss is less than £100

sub_limits.identity_theft_costs: £250 maximum without prior approval; must obtain agreement before incurring costs over £250
sub_limits.alternative_solicitor_fees: If you choose your own solicitor (with written agreement), only paid up to £100+VAT per hour that would have been paid to nominated representative

special_conditions: This is a 'claims made' policy - only covers claims notified within the period of cover
Claims must be reported within 180 days of the event
Must use duty solicitor when interviewed for legal defence claims
Must report identity theft to police within 24 hours and obtain crime reference number
Must contact all banks/financial institutions within 24 hours of discovering identity theft
Must take reasonable steps to minimize loss
Reasonable prospect of success required throughout claim
Authorised representative must act under Conditional Fee Agreement where fees likely recoverable
Where professional fees likely to be recovered, payment not made until conclusion of claim
Must cooperate with insurer, administrator and authorised representative at all times
Boundary disputes at let property only covered after first 180 days of cover
excess_deductible: £250 excess applies to nuisance or trespass claims under Property Protection section. This is payable as soon as the claim is accepted.
geographical_coverage: England, Wales, Scotland, Northern Ireland, Channel Islands and the Isle of Man
age_restrictions: Not specifically mentioned in this policy
pre_existing_conditions: Not applicable to this type of legal expenses insurance. However, incidents must occur during the period of insurance.
cancellation_policy: 14-day cooling-off period from purchase date or receipt of policy documents (whichever is later) with full refund if no claims made or pending. After 14 days, no refund available. Insurer can cancel with 14 days' notice for valid reasons including fraud, non-payment, threatening behavior, non-compliance with terms, or inaccurate information provided.

claims_requirements.notification_timeframe: As soon as possible after becoming aware of an event that may give rise to a claim. Full details must be provided within 180 days of the event. Delays may reduce or prevent assistance.
required_documents: Complete and truthful report of facts giving rise to claim
Documentary evidence in support of claim
For identity theft: police crime reference number
For identity theft: evidence of costs incurred (bills/invoices)
For lost wages: wage/salary slips and employment contract
Any information requested by insurer, administrator or authorised representative
process_steps: Provide complete report and documentary evidence
Administrator/insurer makes preliminary assessment of merits and reasonable prospects of success
If accepted, authorised representative appointed to act on your behalf
If claim appears not to have reasonable prospects, you will be notified in writing
You can request alternative authorised representative for second opinion
If alternative representative also advises no reasonable prospects, no payment made
Authorised representative must provide assessment within 28 days
Six-monthly progress reports required from authorised representative
Written consent required before issuing proceedings, instructing counsel/experts, making appeals, or incurring disbursements
claims_requirements.evidence_requirements: Written contracts required (verbal contracts excluded). Police reports required for identity theft. Complete documentation of incident. Witness details. For property damage: evidence of physical damage. For identity theft: evidence of fraud, crime reference number, evidence of costs incurred.
claims_requirements.claims_contact: Lexelle Limited, PO Box 4428, Sheffield, S9 9DD. Tel: 0114 350 4107. Email: assist@lexelle.com

eligibility_criteria.medical_restrictions: Not applicable to this policy type
eligibility_criteria.occupational_restrictions: Policy excludes matters relating to insured's profession, business or employment (including letting activity). No cover for business ventures outside employment contracts.
eligibility_criteria.residency_requirements: Must have property in England, Wales, Scotland, Northern Ireland, Channel Islands or Isle of Man. Governed by English law with disputes handled in courts of England or country where insured property is situated.
other_restrictions: Must own the let property OR have written authority from owner to sub-let
Let property must not be insured's only or principal home
Let property must be or intended to be let under enforceable residential tenancy agreement or short-term let
Let property cannot be HMO, B&B or hotel
Property must not be unoccupied for 30+ consecutive days or 90+ total days in policy period

policy_definitions.administrator: Lexelle Limited - the firm appointed to administer insurance on behalf of Financial & Legal Insurance Company Limited
policy_definitions.authorised_representative: An appropriately qualified professional person or firm appointed by administrator or insurer to act on your behalf when a claim is made
policy_definitions.civil_claim: A dispute in relation to your contractual, common law and statutory rights for which you are pursuing a remedy
policy_definitions.condition: An obligation that you must perform. If not performed, insurer might not be liable to pay anything under the policy
policy_definitions.date_of_occurrence: The date of the event that leads to a claim; if multiple events at different times, the date of the first event
policy_definitions.defendants_costs: Legal costs and expenses the insured is ordered to pay to another party that can be enforced
policy_definitions.free_legal_advice: Initial verbal legal advice over telephone relating to possible claim. No correspondence entered into
policy_definitions.legal_advice: Any advice provided by insurer's or administrator's in-house legal advisors to assist in claim
policy_definitions.legal_assistance: Actions taken by administrator/authorised representative whilst pursuing accepted claim including professional fees
policy_definitions.let_property: Property identified in schedule (including static caravans and park homes) that is owned or let to insured, not their only/principal home, let/intended to be let under enforceable residential tenancy or short-term let
policy_definitions.legal_proceedings: A claim for damages or compensation pursued in a court of law within England, Wales, Scotland, Northern Ireland, Channel Islands and Isle of Man
policy_definitions.maximum_amount: £50,000 in total, including professional fees and defendants costs, for one or more claims during single period of insurance
policy_definitions.period_of_insurance: The period stated in the schedule
policy_definitions.professional_fees: Fees or costs reasonably incurred by authorised representative with prior authority. Includes disbursements if for third party services, distinct from representative's services, and with prior permission
policy_definitions.reasonable_prospect_of_success: The matter has greater chance than not of being wholly successful at time of reporting and throughout conduct of claim
policy_definitions.small_claim: Claim for damages/compensation which is or may be allocated to small claims jurisdiction of courts (limited to legal advice only under this policy)
policy_definitions.tenant: Person or persons you have agreed can reside at let property and their guests
policy_definitions.unoccupied: Insured property not lived in for 30+ consecutive days or total of 90+ days during period of insurance

time_sensitive_requirements.waiting_periods: Boundary disputes at let property: 180-day waiting period from start of cover
time_sensitive_requirements.notification_deadlines: Must notify of potential claim as soon as possible. Full details within 180 days of event. Delays may invalidate claim or increase costs you must pay.
time_sensitive_requirements.claims_deadlines: 180 days from date of occurrence to provide full claim details. Disputes about insurer decisions must be referred to arbitration within 12 months or claim treated as abandoned.
time_sensitive_requirements.cooling_off_period: 14 days from purchase or receipt of policy documents (whichever is later) for full refund if no claims made/pending

Financial Services Compensation Scheme covers 90% of claim with no upper limit if insurer cannot meet obligations

common_questions.question: Does this policy cover disputes with my tenants?
common_questions.answer: No. The policy explicitly excludes any claims related to your letting activity or against a tenant. This is stated in the general exceptions.

common_questions.question: Can I use this policy for issues at my main home?
common_questions.answer: No. The policy only covers the 'let property' which is defined as property that is NOT your only or principal home and which is let out under a residential tenancy agreement.

common_questions.question: Will this policy cover small claims court cases?
common_questions.answer: Only partially. For small claims, the policy is restricted to legal advice only. It will not pay for professional fees or representation in small claims cases.

common_questions.question: How quickly must I report a potential claim?
common_questions.answer: You must notify as soon as possible and provide full details within 180 days of the event. Delays may restrict cover or make you liable for additional costs incurred due to the delay.
common_questions.section_reference: Making a Claim, General Terms and Conditions

common_questions.question: Can I choose my own solicitor?
common_questions.answer: You can choose your own solicitor with written agreement from the insurer, but they will only pay fees up to £100+VAT per hour (what they would have paid their nominated representative). If legal proceedings are needed or mandatory representation required, you need written permission first.

common_questions.question: What happens if my claim doesn't have reasonable prospects of success?
common_questions.answer: The insurer/administrator will notify you in writing. You can request a second opinion from an alternative authorised representative. If they also say no reasonable prospects, no payment will be made. You can accept this advice (ending cover for that claim) or dispute it through arbitration.
common_questions.section_reference: Making a Claim, Definition of Reasonable Prospect of Success

common_questions.question: Does the policy cover boundary disputes?
common_questions.answer: Only for boundary disputes at your let property, and only if they arise after the first 180 days of cover. Boundary disputes at other properties are excluded.

common_questions.question: Am I covered if prosecuted for issues with my let property?
common_questions.answer: Yes, under Section 4 Legal Defence, but only if you use the duty solicitor when interviewed, there are reasonable prospects of being acquitted, you don't plead guilty, you are acquitted, and you have applied for Legal Aid.

common_questions.question: What should I do if my identity is stolen?
common_questions.answer: Within 24 hours: contact all banks/financial institutions, cancel affected cards, freeze accounts, report to police and get crime reference number, take steps to minimize loss. Then contact the administrator to make a claim. Failure to do these things within 24 hours may result in claim rejection.
common_questions.section_reference: Section 5 - Identity Theft, Conditions Relating to Identity Theft

common_questions.question: Can I cancel the policy and get a refund?
common_questions.answer: Yes, within 14 days of purchase or receiving documents (whichever is later) you get a full refund if no claims made/pending. After 14 days, no refund is available. Note: your broker/agent may charge additional cancellation fees.

common_questions.question: What is the maximum the policy will pay out?
common_questions.answer: £50,000 in total for all claims during one policy period, including professional fees and defendant's costs. For identity theft specifically, there is a £5,000 sub-limit for reimbursement of costs.
common_questions.section_reference: Definition of Maximum Amount, Section 5 - Identity Theft

common_questions.question: Will the policy pay if I lose my case?
common_questions.answer: No. The policy does not cover professional fees or defendant's costs where your defence to a claim is not wholly successful. You must win completely.

common_questions.question: Can I use the 24/7 legal advice service instead of making a claim?
common_questions.answer: The 24/7 service provides initial telephone advice only and is separate from making a claim. You must not delay reporting a claim while using the helpline. It provides general advice only and cannot replace making a formal claim.

common_questions.question: Are verbal agreements covered?
common_questions.answer: No. Verbal contracts are specifically excluded. The contract or agreement must be confirmed in writing.

common_questions.question: What if my let property is a House in Multiple Occupation (HMO)?
common_questions.answer: HMOs, B&Bs and hotels are completely excluded from this policy. The policy will not provide any cover for these types of properties.
